title: Interests
text:
As a wizard and scholar of Middle-earth, I have been studying the magic of the natural world for centuries. Through my self-portraits, I aim to capture the essence of my own being and reflect on my own journey through time. Each photograph is a reflection of my own experiences and emotions. Through my photography, I hope to offer a glimpse into my life as a scholar and adventurer, and inspire others to reflect on their own journeys through the world.

title: Welcome to my website!
text:
Twitter
  
  
    
     LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Email
  




Welcome to my website!
My name is Graham Stockdale, I’m a physician-scientist at the Cleveland Clinic in Cleveland, OH. Welcome to my website!
I’m currently a fellow in the department of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. I’m also in my first year of an NIH sponsored T32 grant and currently completing an MS in Biomedical Health Informatics (BHI) at Case Western Reserve University.
Clinically my interests are very broad, ranging from the micro (proteomics, transcriptomics) to the macro (health policy/econoimcs) and everything in between (organ based physiology, comparative physiology, heart-lung interaction, physics of ventilators, echocardiography in critical care).
In this website you’ll be able to see some of the projects I’m currently working on, non-clinical interets, curriculum vitae, and more!
Don’t be a stranger!

title: Projects
text: One of our current projects is using D-dimer as a marker for defining a new phenotype of pulmonary hypertension (PH). We are currently working to understand if elevated D-dimer and it’s relationship to in-situ thrombosis is an innate feature of PH or consequence of the decreased calibur of the pulmonary vessels, increased turbulence -> endothelial destruction -> and resultant thrombosis. Stay Tuned for more.

title: Projects
text:
A new paradigm in PH
The prior 5 group model of PH is out of date. It was a model of convenience that related different subset of diseases to the organ system that was thought to cause the primary insult leading to the subsequent development of PH. Yet we have know for some time that this is a grouping of convenience and not rooted in rigorous scientific understanding of the underlying disease process. Over the coming months we hope to role out a new PH grouping, one that is rooted in both physiologic but also transcriptomic data.

title: Interests
text:
Complex hemodynamics, phenotyping shock, and organ-system physiology are some of my favorite topics. Below are some resources for using the VExUS score for measuring venous congestion in critical illness. Enjoy!
